thread.title: Astoria Column reopens to public after 'stunning' restoration
thread.title_full: Astoria Column reopens to public after 'stunning' restoration | OregonLive.com

author: Amy Wang | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Astoria Column reopens to public after 'stunning' restoration
text:
After five months under wraps, the Astoria Column reopened to the public Saturday, looking as if it had traveled back in time to its opening day in 1926.
So said Jordan Schnitzer, founder and president of the nonprofit Friends of Astoria Column , who's been working for nearly three decades to help preserve the historical marker.
Visitors will see the column "looking like it was done by the artist the day before and you just happened to get there," he said Saturday. He called the restoration "stunning."
There was no grand reopening event Saturday. Astoria Mayor Arline LaMear said the Friends group and the city may schedule one later, after other work is complete. "They want to wait until everything is in good order before we have a grand opening," she said.
The 125-foot-tall column, which sits on a hill overlooking the city, was built as one of 12 historical markers that stretch westward from St. Paul, Minnesota, to commemorate the settlers who helped expand the United States to the Pacific Ocean. It's modeled after Rome's Trajan's Column , which tells the tale of an emperor's major military victory.
Astoria's column has 525 feet of murals that depict historic events such as the end of the Lewis and Clark Expedition and Capt. Robert Gray's discovery of the Columbia River. Attilio Pusterla created the art using a technique known as sgraffito .
Schnitzer, president of Portland's Harsch Investment Properties, said he got involved with preserving the Astoria Column because he has a home in nearby Gearhart and has been visiting Astoria for decades. By the 1980s, he said, the effects of time and weather on the column were obvious. He contacted the mayor and a public-private partnership was born, with Schnitzer creating the Friends of Astoria Column to raise funds.
This year's project wasn't the first time that efforts have been made to restore the column, but none of the previous work was satisfactory, Schnitzer said. "When you restore something as magnificent as the Astoria Column, it truly is an art and a science," he said.
Friends of Astoria Column had originally planned a $1 million campaign, but started the restoration work in May after reaching the $600,000 mark. "We didn't want to go one more year with the weather battering our beloved column," Schnitzer said.
The nonprofit will now work on raising $500,000 more to finish the rest of the work, such as repairing pavers loosened by an earlier seismic upgrading of the column's foundation and installing LED lights.
Schnitzer said that while the Astoria Column has nothing on historic sites elsewhere in terms of age, it's venerable for its home state.
"We don't have that many structures like this in Oregon," he said. "Therefore we have a greater obligation to take care of it, and it's something that belongs to every single Oregonian."
